title.narrative: Providing equitable community based health access to 90.000 inhabitants of the sub prefectures of Markounda (Ouham), Koui and Ngaoundaye (Ouham Pendé).

description.narrative:
The requested CHF support is required to enable MENTOR to pursue with an innovative, community based approach that significantly improves access to essential health care among the most vulnerable populations. It will allow for recently set up extensive networks of Community based Health Workers (CHWs) to consolidate the lifesaving activities provided to more than 80.000 people living in remote areas with no access to health care at conventional health structures and of whom many have been recently displaced. 64 CHWs, equipped, trained and supervised by MENTOR, will ensure effective access to quality diagnosis and treatment for essential diseases such as malaria (endemic in the targeted areas) and waterborne diseases. In parallel, in order to ensure an efficient referral level of complicated cases, support will equally be provided to three health posts in order to cover important gaps in functional referral level health structures. In order to facilitate the physical transport of severe cases, transportation costs will be reimbursed to selected ‘mototaxi’ working in the individual communities. Health education activities will be fully integrated at all levels of the project through regular sensitization sessions carried out by the CHWs as well as through large scale prevention sessions (film projection, quizzes, sports arrangements) with active community participation. While this project is designed to ensure geographical and financial (all services are for free) access to essential health care to all population groups, regardless of age, gender, ethnic group, physical disabilities etc, special focus, both within case management and in terms of health education and disease prevention, is given to pregnant women to encourage safe pregnancy and delivery as well as to children under 5 years who are the most at risk to die from complications of malaria and waterborne diseases.
Exchanges with the communities are at the heart of the project and, in addition to regular contact with the target population during monthly on-the–job coaching sessions with the CHWs, Focus Group Discussions (FGD) will be set up to identify vulnerable groups within the communities and to assess their existing capacities and their needs. FGDs are designed as “gender friendly”, with female MENTOR assessment teams working with women, and mal MENTOR team members leading male groups.
The project will work the following sub-districts (“communes”): Markounda (in Markounda), Koui (in Koui) and Dikouli, Lim, Kodi, Yeme, Mbili (in Ngaoundaye). The health facilities supported are: Kadjama Kota (Markounda), Kella Mawelé (Koui), Mann, Kounang and Mbéréguili (Ngaoudaye).
